messages.text: Yep that was very early on and was reasonable in that case, but removing a package because it was discontinued would break any code that isn't/won't be updated to use its successor. That can happen in corporate environments where the versions of things need to remain stable and particular.

messages.text:
While things are never and will never (exceptions aside) be deleted from registry at some point we might have the option to `unlist` them s that they don’t tab-complete, and maybe don’t block the name from being used for something else, and maybe show a warning on install.

<https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/issues/2194>

root.text: I'm working on an experimental package that may ultimately be absorbed into another package. Is that a good reason to not register it? Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry? I'd like to avoid potentially confusing users if there are two packages with similar names but one is discontinued.

elements.text: I'm working on an experimental package that may ultimately be absorbed into another package. Is that a good reason to not register it? Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry? I'd like to avoid potentially confusing users if there are two packages with similar names but one is discontinued.
While things are never and will never (exceptions aside) be deleted from registry at some point we might have the option to
unlist
them s that they don’t tab-complete, and maybe don’t block the name from being used for something else, and maybe show a warning on install.

messages.text: Re- <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/funding-community-projects/56288/2|https://discourse.julialang.org/t/funding-community-projects/56288/2>, someone should submit a proposal to tackle the RegistryCI issue backlog / add more <#CED4U82BC|pkg-trust> checks etc! The General registry is vital infrastructure and could use more help to stay healthy as the ecosystem grows, imo. (I’d submit one but I don’t have enough time to do the project!)

attachments.title: Funding Community Projects
attachments.text: Hi fellow Julians! Many of you probably know that the Julia project uses the NumFOCUS, an US non-profit organisation as it’s fiscal sponsor. This means that income for the project is collected in accounts of that organisation, and our expenses are paid though there. The primary source of income is via sponsorship of JuliaCon, although individual sponsorships are now significant as well. Major expenses are again for JuliaCon, as well for our summer-of-code projects. As a result of careful stewa...

<https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/31246>

messages.text:
> It looks like empty packages generated by PkgTemplates.jl are automatically accepted.
What do you mean with this. All packages are accepted if they pass the automatic checks. These automatic checks does not involve there being code in the package (maybe they should). But I don't see how PkgTemplates is relevant to this?

elements.text: It looks like empty packages generated by PkgTemplates.jl are automatically accepted.

messages.text: Sorry, I don't know how the automatic checks work, and I thought they check for the minimal structure, and using that package, you get that minimal structure from the beginning, even with an empty module in src. But it seems that I have just interpreted correlation as causation. In any case, it sounds sensible to check for the content of the package module. Here there is another example: <https://github.com/Humans-of-Julia/ModernGraphs.jl/blob/main/src/ModernGraphs.jl>

messages.text: For what it's worth, these two mentioned packages involve the same people and come from github organizations which already have registered packages with some substance, so I'm not particularly worried about these, even though the timing of the registrations may be questionable.

elements.text: For what it's worth, these two mentioned packages involve the same people and come from github organizations which already have registered packages with some substance, so I'm not particularly worried about these, even though the timing of the registrations may be questionable.

messages.text: Yes, It is not a problem in those cases as code is being added with time :slightly_smiling_face: But, it is dangerous that people can start publishing packages after adding meaningful code in it.

messages.text:
Hey everyone, I'm trying to clean up the permissions in the JuliaRegistries organization. I've been organizing the repos into teams, and then putting people on teams. Unfortunately, when you add someone to a team, GitHub likes to automatically "watch" all of those repos. So if you are a JuliaRegistries member, you may find that you have suddenly been "subscribed" to multiple JuliaRegistries repos that you weren't previously watching.

Unfortunately you will need to manually click "unwatch" from any repo that you don't want to subscribe to.

Sorry about this inconvenience! I don't know of any way that I can disable this in GitHub.

elements.text:
Hey everyone, I'm trying to clean up the permissions in the JuliaRegistries organization. I've been organizing the repos into teams, and then putting people on teams. Unfortunately, when you add someone to a team, GitHub likes to automatically "watch" all of those repos. So if you are a JuliaRegistries member, you may find that you have suddenly been "subscribed" to multiple JuliaRegistries repos that you weren't previously watching.

Unfortunately you will need to manually click "unwatch" from any repo that you don't want to subscribe to.

Sorry about this inconvenience! I don't know of any way that I can disable this in GitHub.
